The {{nihongo foot|'''SG-1000'''|エスジー・セン|Esu Jī Sen|lead=yes|group=lower-alpha}}<!-- See [[WP:JFN]] --> is a [[home video game console]] manufactured by [[Sega]] and released in Japan, Australia, New Zealand, and other regions. It was Sega's first entry into the home video game hardware business. Introduced in 1983, the SG-1000 was released on the same day that [[Nintendo]] released the [[Family Computer]] in Japan. The SG-1000 was released in several forms, including the '''SC-3000''' computer and the redesigned '''SG-1000 II'''{{efn|{{nihongo|SG-1000 II|エスジー・セン・ツー|Esu Jī Sen Tsū}}<!-- See [[WP:JFN]] -->}} released in 1984. A third iteration of the console, the '''Sega Mark III''', was released in 1985. It provided a custom video display processor over previous iterations and served as the basis for the [[Master System]] in 1986, Sega's first internationally-released console.

Developed in response to a downturn in arcades in 1982, the SG-1000 was created on the advice of [[Hayao Nakayama]], president of Sega Enterprises, Ltd. Shortly after the release, Sega Enterprises was sold to [[SCSK|CSK Corporation]], which was followed by the release of the SG-1000 II. The SC-3000 and the SG-1000 line both support a library of 76 [[ROM cartridge]] games and 29 [[Sega Card|Sega My Card]] games, all of which are fully compatible with the Mark III and the Japanese version of the Master System.

In the early 1980s, [[Sega|Sega Enterprises, Inc.]], then a subsidiary of [[Gulf and Western]], was one of the top five arcade game manufacturers active in the United States, as company revenues rose to $214 million.<ref>{{cite magazine| url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/1994-02-20/sega| title=Sega!| magazine=Businessweek| date=February 1994| accessdate=October 10, 2013| first1=Richard| last1=Brandt| first2=Neil| last2=Gross| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203121725/http://www.businessweek.com/stories/1994-02-20/sega| archivedate=December 3, 2013| df=mdy-all}}</ref>  A downturn in the arcade business starting in 1982 seriously hurt the company, leading Gulf and Western to sell its North American arcade manufacturing organization and the licensing rights for its arcade games to [[Bally Manufacturing]].<ref name="NYTimes">{{cite news |title=What's New In Video Games; Taking the Zing Out of the Arcade Boom |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/24/business/what-s-new-in-video-games-taking-the-zing-out-of-the-arcade-boom.html |newspaper=New York Times |date=October 24, 1982 |accessdate=November 27, 2013 |first=Andrew |last=Pollack |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219200336/http://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/24/business/what-s-new-in-video-games-taking-the-zing-out-of-the-arcade-boom.html |archivedate=December 19, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="herald">{{cite news |title=The Bottom Line |url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:MIHB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB35D5F24528A22&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0ECC86DE7A4704AD |newspaper=Miami Herald {{subscription required|via=[[NewsBank]]}} |date=August 27, 1983 |accessdate=October 10, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110080330/http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004 |archivedate=November 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>  The company retained Sega's North American [[research and development|R&D]] operation, as well as its Japanese subsidiary, Sega Enterprises, Ltd.  With its arcade business in decline, Sega Enterprises, Ltd. president [[Hayao Nakayama]] advocated that the company leverage its hardware expertise to move into the home console market in Japan, which was in its infancy at the time.<ref name="Wired1">{{Cite journal| url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/1.06/sega_pr.html| title=The Next Level: Sega's Plans for World Domination| journal=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]| publisher=[[Condé Nast|Condé Nast Publications]]| date=December 1993| accessdate=October 9, 2013| first=John| last=Battelle| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502064808/http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/1.06/sega_pr.html| archivedate=May 2, 2012| df=mdy-all}}</ref>  Nakayama received permission to proceed.<ref name="Wired">{{Cite news| url=https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2009/10/sega-sg-1000/| title=Playing the SG-1000, Sega's First Game Machine| publisher=Wired Magazine's online site| date=October 2009| accessdate=October 5, 2009| first=Chris| last=Kohler| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101073612/http://www.wired.com/gamelife/2009/10/sega-sg-1000/| archivedate=January 1, 2014| df=mdy-all}}</ref> The first model to be developed was the SC-3000, a computer with a built-in keyboard, but when Sega learned of Nintendo's plans to release a games-only console, they began developing the SG-1000 alongside the SC-3000.<ref name="Retro163" />  To keep costs down while ensuring sufficient longevity, Sega opted to create the platform from popular off-the-shelf components.<ref name="Retro163">{{cite magazine|last=Marley|first=Scott |date=December 2016 |title=SG-1000 |magazine=[[Retro Gamer]] |issue=163|pages=56-61|publisher=[[Future Publishing]]}}</ref> 

The SG-1000 was first released in Japan on July 15, 1983, at [[Japanese yen|JP¥]]15,000.<ref name="Sega">{{cite web|title=SG-1000|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140716103528/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/|archivedate=July 16, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> It was released on the same day as [[Nintendo]] launched the [[Nintendo Entertainment System|Family Computer]] (Famicom) in Japan.<ref name="Wired" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://kotaku.com/the-story-of-segas-first-console-which-was-not-the-mas-5888800|title=The Story of Sega's First Console, Which Was Not The Master System|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|date=January 19, 2017|website=Kotaku|publisher=[[Gizmodo Media Group]]|access-date=March 3, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170306195938/http://kotaku.com/the-story-of-segas-first-console-which-was-not-the-mas-5888800|archivedate=March 6, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> It was released simultaneously with the SC-3000,<ref name="Wired" /><ref name="Sega" /><ref name="Gamershigh" /> also known as the Sega Personal Computer SC-3000,<ref name="SegaSC">{{cite web|title=SC-3000|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/|language=Japanese|publisher=Sega Corporation|accessdate=February 15, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140716103831/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/|archivedate=July 16, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> as well as the upgraded SC-3000H.<ref name="SegaSCH">{{cite web|title=SC-3000H|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/sc3000h.html|language=Japanese|publisher=Sega Corporation|accessdate=February 15, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222070516/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/sc3000h.html|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Though Sega themselves only released the SG-1000 in Japan, rebranded versions were released in several other markets worldwide.  Released at nearly the same time as the Japanese version, the SG-1000 was released in Australia through [[John Sands (company)|John Sands Electronics]]<ref name="Wired" /> and in New Zealand by [[Grandstand Leisure]].<ref name="Retro163" />  The console also saw a release in Italy and Spain,<ref name="Retroinspection">{{cite journal|author=McFerran, Damien|title=Retroinspection: Master System|journal=[[Retro Gamer]]|publisher=Imagine Publishing|issue=44|pages=48–53}}</ref> but was not released in the larger video game markets of the United States, United Kingdom, or Germany.<ref name=":0" /> Despite this, an unauthorized [[Clone (computing)|clone]] system known as the [[Dina (video game console)|Telegames Personal Arcade]] was produced and made available in the United States and Taiwan, and is able to play SG-1000 and [[ColecoVision]] games.<ref name="Wired" />  An additional release of the SG-1000 in Taiwan was done by Aaronix.<ref name="Retro163" /> The console enjoyed a brief period of popularity in Taiwan before the market was taken over by cheaper [[Nintendo Entertainment System hardware clone|Famicom clones]].<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Marley|first=Scott |date=December 2016 |title=The Rare Jewels from Taiwan... |magazine=[[Retro Gamer]] |issue=163|page=61|publisher=[[Future Publishing]]}}</ref>

Due in part to the SG-1000's steadier stream of releases (21 SG-1000 games by the end of 1983, as compared to only 9 Famicom games), and in part to a recall on Famicom units necessitated by a faulty circuit, the SG-1000 chalked up 160,000 units in sales in 1983, far exceeding Sega's projection of 50,000 units.<ref name="Retro163" /> Former Sega consumer hardware development head Hideki Sato stated that because Sega had not predicted the SG-1000 would sell so well, the company became more enamored with developing video game consoles.<ref name=":02">{{Cite magazine|last=Sato|first=Hideki|date=November 1998|title=The History of Sega Console Hardware|url=http://shmuplations.com/segahistory/|magazine=[[Famitsu DC|Famitsu]]|language=Japanese|publisher=[[ASCII Corporation]]|doi=|pmid=|access-date=March 5, 2019|via=Shmuplations}}</ref>  Despite this, the three launch games, all of which were ported from [[List of Sega arcade system boards|Sega's VIC dual-arcade board]], lacked the name recognition of Famicom launch games ''[[Donkey Kong (video game)|Donkey Kong]]'', ''[[Donkey Kong Jr.]]'', and ''[[Popeye (video game)|Popeye]]''.<ref name="Retro163" />

Shortly after launch, Gulf and Western began to divest itself of its non-core businesses after the death of company founder [[Charles Bluhdorn]],<ref name="herald2">{{cite news |title=G&W Wins Cheers $1 Billion Spinoff Set |url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:MIHB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB35D45A7276DB8&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0ECC86DE7A4704AD |newspaper=Miami Herald {{subscription required|via=[[NewsBank]]}} |date=August 16, 1983 |accessdate=October 10, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110080330/http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004 |archivedate=November 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> so Nakayama and former Sega CEO [[David Rosen (business)|David Rosen]] arranged a management buyout of the Japanese subsidiary in 1984 with financial backing from [[SCSK|CSK Corporation]], a prominent Japanese software company. Nakayama was then installed as CEO of the new Sega Enterprises, Ltd.<ref name="Kent2">{{cite book |ref=CITEREFKent2001 |last=Kent |first=Steven L. |authorlink=Steven L. Kent |title=The Ultimate History of Video Games: The Story Behind the Craze that Touched our Lives and Changed the World |year=2001 |publisher=Prima Publishing |location=Roseville, California |isbn=0-7615-3643-4 |chapter=The Birth of Sega|page=343}}</ref> Following the buyout, Sega released another console, the '''SG-1000 II''', on July 31, 1984<ref name="Gamershigh">{{cite book|title=Gamer's High! Futabasha Super Mook|date=2015|publisher=Futabasha|isbn=978-4-575-45554-0|page=54|language=Japanese}}</ref><ref name="Retroinspection" /> at JP¥15,000.<ref name="SG1000_2">{{cite web|title=SG-1000 II|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000_2/|language=Japanese|publisher=Sega Corporation|accessdate=February 15, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130209183714/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000_2/|archivedate=February 9, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The SG-1000 II replaced the hardwired joystick with two detachable joypads.<ref name="Wired" />  Sato disliked the original cartridges, saying they looked like "small black tombstones" when inserted in the console, and later remarked that his proudest achievement of the SG-1000 era was replacing them with the "cheerier", pocket-sized Sega My Cards.<ref name="Retro163" /> Sega also employed popular [[owarai]] comedy duo [[Tunnels (owarai)|Tunnels]] to provide celebrity endorsement for the console.<ref name="Retro163" />

By 1984, the Famicom's success began to outpace the SG-1000. The Famicom had more advanced hardware, allowing it to perform smoother scrolling and more colorful sprites, and Nintendo boosted its games library by courting [[third-party developer]]s, whereas Sega was less than eager to collaborate with the same companies they were competing with in arcades.<ref name="Retro163" /> The SG-1000 was also coming up against game consoles from companies including [[Tomy]] and [[Bandai]].<ref name="Wired" /> This would result in the release of the Sega Mark III in Japan in 1985, which later became the [[Master System]] worldwide.<ref name="Retroinspection" /> The last cartridge released was ''Portrait of Loretta'' on February 18, 1987.<ref name="SegaSoft">{{cite web|title=SG-1000|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/soft.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130209183709/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/soft.html|archivedate=February 9, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>  In 2006, the [[GameTap]] subscription gaming service added an [[emulator]] of the SG-1000, and several playable titles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/gametap-celebrates-sonics-15th-anniversary-with-rare-content-from-import-only-console-lock-on-genesis-games-and-new-tv-on-the-web-programming|title=GameTap Celebrates Sonic's 15th Anniversary With Rare Content From Import-Only Console, Lock-On Genesis Games, And New TV-On-The-Web Programming|last=|first=|date=June 23, 2006|website=GamesIndustry International|publisher=[[Eurogamer#Subsidiaries|Gamer Network]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222201853/http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/gametap-celebrates-sonics-15th-anniversary-with-rare-content-from-import-only-console-lock-on-genesis-games-and-new-tv-on-the-web-programming|archivedate=February 22, 2014|deadurl=no|accessdate=February 27, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>

==Technical specifications==
[[Image:TMS9928A 01.jpg|thumb|right|TMS9928A video display processor, as used in the SG-1000]]
The SG-1000 is powered by an [[8-bit]] [[Zilog Z80]] [[central processing unit]] running at 3.58 [[Hertz|MHz]] for the SG-1000 and SG-1000 II,<ref name="SGTech">{{cite web|title=SG-1000 Technical specifications|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/data.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203134913/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/data.html|archivedate=December 3, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="SG2Tech">{{cite web|title=SG-1000 II Technical specifications|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000_2/data.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222070408/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000_2/data.html|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and at 4 MHz for the SC-3000.<ref name="SCTech">{{cite web|title=SC-3000 Technical specifications|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/data.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006113401/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/data.html|archivedate=October 6, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>  Its video processor is a [[Texas Instruments TMS9928A]], capable of displaying up to 16 colors, and its sound processor is a [[Texas Instruments SN76489]].  All three chips were also used in the ColecoVision.<ref name="Wired"/>  The system includes 8 [[kilobit|kbit]] (1 [[kilobyte|KB]]) of [[random access memory]] (RAM)<ref name="SGTech"/>  The controller is hardwired to the system in the original model, and detachable in the SG-1000 II.  Video and audio output are supplied through an [[RF switch]].<ref name="Wired"/>  Power is supplied through a 9 V [[DC connector]] connected to an [[AC adapter]].<ref name="SGTech"/><ref name="SG2Tech"/><ref name="SCTech"/>

Several peripherals exist for the SG-1000 series.  Available at ¥13,800 at its time of release, the SK-1100 keyboard connects through the expansion slot and is compatible with all models.<ref name=SK>{{cite web|title=SK-1100|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/sk1100.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222070731/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/sk1100.html|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>  Multiple [[video game controller|controllers]] were created, including the SJ-200 [[joystick]] attached to the SG-1000, and the SJ-150 joypad, made for use with the SG-1000 II.  A racing wheel known as the SH-400 was made for use with games such as ''[[Monaco GP (video game)|Monaco GP]]''.<ref name=controllers>{{cite web|title=SG-1000 controllers|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/controller.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222070624/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/controller.html|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>  The C-1000 Card Catcher, sold at ¥1,000, allowing players to play [[Sega Card|Sega My Card]] titles.<ref name=card>{{cite web|title=Card catcher|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/c1000.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222070728/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sg1000/c1000.html|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>  Additional accessories existed solely for use with the SC-3000, including the SR-1000 [[cassette deck]],<ref name=cassette>{{cite web|title=SR-1000|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/sr1000.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222070726/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/sr1000.html|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> the SP-400 4-color [[plotter|plotter printer]],<ref name=printer>{{cite web|title=SP-400|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/sp400.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222070626/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/sp400.html|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and the SF-7000 expansion device which adds a [[floppy disk]] drive and additional memory.<ref name=sf7000>{{cite web|title=SF-7000|publisher=[[Sega|Sega Corporation]]|url=http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/sf7000.html|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 12, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222070730/http://sega.jp/fb/segahard/sc3000/sf7000.html|archivedate=February 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>

==Game library==
[[Image:SG1000 cartridge.jpg|thumb|left|100px|[[Monaco GP (video game)|Monaco GP]] cartridge]]
[[Image:Girl'sGardenLet'sMarryHim.PNG|thumb|right|175px|''[[Girl's Garden]]'', developed by [[Yuji Naka]]]]
Sega's software library for the SG-1000 and SC-3000 comprises 42 game cartridges and 29 Sega My Card releases that required the Card Catcher add-on. There were also 26 educational and programming cartridges for the SC-3000 that could only be played on the SG-1000 with the SK-1100 keyboard peripheral.<ref name="SegaSoft"/> Titles for the system include ''[[Flicky]]'', ''[[Congo Bongo]]'', ''[[Galaga|Sega-Galaga]]'', and ''[[Girl's Garden]]'', the first video game programmed by [[Sonic the Hedgehog (1991 video game)|''Sonic the Hedgehog'']] developer [[Yuji Naka]].  The library included licensed titles, such as ''[[Golgo 13#Video games|Golgo 13]]''.  Packaging and game manuals came with both Japanese and English text until 1984, when manuals were switched to Japanese only and the size of the cartridge box was reduced.<ref name="Wired"/>  Hideki Sato stated that Sega lacked adequate staff to develop games for the console at the time.<ref name=":02" /> SC-3000/SG-1000 games were continued to be produced after the launch of the Mark III in [[1985 in video gaming|1985]]. The last two SC-3000/SG-1000 cartridge games were ''[[The Castle (video game)|The Castle]]'' in [[1986 in video gaming|1986]] and ''Portrait of Loretta'' in [[1987 in video gaming|1987]]. The final Sega My Card game for the SC-3000/SG-1000 was ''[[The Black Onyx]]'', also in [[1987 in video gaming|1987]].<ref name="sc3k_software_list">{{cite web|url=https://sega.jp/history/hard/sc3000/software.html|title=ソフトウェア一覧 - SC-3000 - セガハード大百科 - セガ|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Sega]]|language=Japanese|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 28, 2019}}</ref>

==Legacy==
The SG-1000 made little impact on the video game industry, but has been recognized for being Sega's first video game console. ''[[Retro Gamer]]'' writer Damien McFerran said it was an "abject failure", but called it and the SG-1000 II "the Japanese forefathers of the Master System".<ref name="Retroinspection"/>  Writing for ''Wired'', Chris Kohler criticized the poor response of the controller's joystick and the lack of an [[RCA connector|RCA]] output. He said the release timing hurt its success; "[al]though its graphics were of better quality than most consoles on the market, it had the bad luck to be released in the same month as Nintendo's world-changing Famicom, which had killer apps like ''Donkey Kong'' and could run circles around Sega's hardware."<ref name="Wired"/>  Of its legacy, Kohler said, "Few have heard of it, even fewer have played it, and the games weren't that great anyway."<ref name="Wired"/> By contrast, Luke Plunkett of ''[[Kotaku]]'' recognized that "while all this makes it sound like the SG-1000 was a bit of a misfire, it was still important in the development of Sega's home console business."<ref name=":0" />

Hideki Sato reflected positively on the innovations in the development of the SG-1000, but admitted that the console had limitations because of how new the market was and that Sega was inexperienced in developing for a video game console at the time.  According to Sato, "The problem was, while we knew how to make arcade games, we didn’t really know anything about console development. In fact, the very idea of a “consumer” market for video games was unheard of then: back then it was just a 'new business' idea."<ref name=":02" />
